Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 333415: Air-Conditioning and Warm Air Heating Equipment and Commercial and Industrial Refrigeration Equipmen
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
NAICS Translation: 335222: Household Refrigerator and Home Freezer Manufacturing
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: Panasonic Corp. and its subsidiary, SANYO Electric Co. Ltd., agreed to plead guilty and to pay a total of $56.5 million in criminal fines for their roles in separate price-fixing conspiracies involving automotive parts and battery cells.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/panasonic-and-its-subsidiary-sanyo-agree-plead-guilty-separate-price-fixing-conspiracies

Description: Panasonic Corporation and a Whirlpool Corporation subsidiary, Embraco North America Inc., agreed to plead guilty and to pay a total of $140.9 million in criminal fines for their role in an international conspiracy to fix the prices of refrigerant compressors used in refrigerators and freezers in homes and businesses.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/panasonic-corp-and-whirlpool-corp-subsidiary-agree-plead-guilty-role-price-fixing-conspiracy

NAICS Translation: 333415: Air-Conditioning and Warm Air Heating Equipment and Commercial and Industrial Refrigeration Equipmen
Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php

Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php

Description: Panasonic Avionics Corporation (PAC), a subsidiary of multinational electronics company Panasonic Corporation, agreed to pay a $137.4 million criminal penalty to resolve charges arising out of a scheme to retain consultants for improper purposes and conceal payments to third-party sales agents, in violation of the accounting provisions of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/panasonic-avionics-corporation-agrees-pay-137-million-resolve-foreign-corrupt-practices-act

Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that Japan-based Panasonic Corp. would pay more than $143 million to resolve Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and accounting fraud violations involving its global avionics business.
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/news/press-release/2018-73

Description: The award was upheld by the 8th Circuit in ruling No. 03-2582.
Private Litigation Case Title: Rowe v. Hussmann Corp., et al
Info Source: https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-8th-circuit/1033354.html

Description: The California Attorney General announced settlements resolving allegations that LG, Hitachi, Panasonic, Toshiba, and Samsung, companies all based in Japan or Korea, fixed prices on cathode ray tubes from 1995 to 2007.
Info Source: https://www.oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/attorney-general-kamala-d-harris-announces-settlements-totaling-495-million-lg

Description: LG Electronics, Panasonic, Samsung, Sharp and Sony agreed to pay a total of $1.25 million and contribute $1.125 million of audio-visual equipment to Californian schools and institutions in settlement of allegations by District Attorneys in seven counties that they violated state law by stating TV screen sizes rounded to the nearest inch. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amounts were divided equally among the five.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20131122125231/http://da.co.la.ca.us/mr/archive/2011/010311a.htm
